content:
I’m finishing my PhD in Chemical Engineering at MIT in CSAIL. My research focuses on analytical approaches to understand how enzymes facilitate virtually impossible reactions at ambient conditions. During my doctorate, I studied how several enzymes catalyze reactions through an atomistic perspective using molecular dynamics coupled with quantum chemistry (QM/MM). From these simulations, we’ve created predictive models capable of identifying both the structural features most indicative of successful reactions, and the electronic underpinnings of such methods.
I believe strongly in collaboration, teaching, and mentorship. Please feel free to email me if you’d like to learn more, or get involved.
summary: I’m finishing my PhD in Chemical Engineering at MIT in CSAIL. My research focuses on analytical approaches to understand how enzymes facilitate virtually impossible reactions at ambient conditions. During my doctorate, I studied how several enzymes catalyze reactions through an atomistic perspective using molecular dynamics coupled with quantum chemistry (QM/MM).
title: Natasha Seelam

summary: Using umbrella-methods, we uncover reaction landscapes of how proteins facilitate chemistry to uncover novel insight into mechanisms.
title: Capturing the free-energy of protein-facilitated reactivity

summary: Every atom in a protein is subject to forces that allow them to move. We leverage the use of path-sampling algorithms to explore how proteins employ dynamics in order to cross reaction barriers, and how this gives rise to reactivity.
title: Dynamics in enzyme catalysis

summary: Structural features can be highly predictive of successful reactions. In the following work, we explore how geometry of the active-site relates to quantitated electronic mechanism in an enzyme.
title: Electronic underpinnings of protein mechanisms
